back: A simple plotting interface in Matplotlib (Pyplot) where you call functions directly (e.g., plt.plot()), and it manages figures and axes for you.
A plotting interface where you create Figure and Axes objects explicitly and call methods on them for fine-grained control over layout and appearance.
Matplotlib’s mode of keeping track of the current figure and axes so that plotting functions apply to them without needing to pass them explicitly.
The top-level container for all plot elements in Matplotlib—think of it as the window or canvas that holds one or more Axes.
The individual plotting area within a Figure where data is drawn, including its own x- and y-axis, labels, and ticks.
Graphs that connect data points with lines to show relationships or trends between two numerical variables.
A box in the plot that explains the symbols, colors, or line styles used to represent different data series.
A shorthand notation (e.g., 'ro--') used in plotting functions to specify color, marker, and line style in one string.
Plots that display individual data points as markers, useful for visualizing relationships or clusters in two variables.
The symbol (e.g., 'o', '^', 's') used to represent each data point in a plot.
Mappings from numerical data values to colors, often used in heatmaps or gradient-based plots.
Smoothed representations of data distributions using kernel density estimation instead of discrete histograms.
The tick marks and labels along an axis that indicate the scale or specific data values.
The lines denoting the boundaries of the plotting area (the borders around the Axes).
Multiple Axes placed in a grid within one Figure, allowing you to display several plots side by side.
